entry.title: Re: Automating Message Retries in SAP CPI with the Data Store Channel
entry.content:
@varun1

As mentioned in the blog, you’ll still need to re-invoke the iFlow when an error occurs. Instead of re-executing the entire iFlow, call only the local process where the error happened. To enable this, save the payload immediately before the error point and architect the iFlow as a set of smaller local processes where errors can occur. For each local process, persist a parameter that indicates the exact failure location; pass that parameter to the exception subprocess so it knows where to resume or handle the error.

Note: I haven’t implemented this logic yet  this is a proposed design approach I’m considering

How to make 'Tax code' field mandatory in purchase order

entry.title: Re: we want to apply tax code is mandatory for PO creation .
entry.content:
Hi,

You can use BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PO_FLDCNTRL_SIMPLE to modify the properties of specific fields that appear on the user interface of the apps:

  • Manage Purchase Orders on item level in the section Process Control
  • Create Purchase Order - Advanced on item level on the tabs Delivery and Invoice.

The SAP GUI transactions ME21N, ME22N, ME23N are also affected by this
BAdI.
You can make the fields hidden, read-only, mandatory, or optional as per
your requirements.

Using the BAdI you can change the field control properties for the TAXCODE field.

If user's BAdI implementation defines the status of a field as 'Mandatory' that SAP has defined as 'Optional', the system does not perform a check and does not output an error message.

The user can implement the BAdI Check of Purchase Order Before Saving (BD_MMPUR_FINAL_CHECK_PO) to perform their own checks and to output the corresponding error messages.

Refer to:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003268822

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003468887

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Error When Logging into CBC
entry.content:
Dear @naoakisaruyama,

This error is coming from SAP Cloud Identity Services Identity Authentication (IAS), not directly from CBC itself.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/authorization-and-trust-management-service/authorization-and-trust-management/token-retrieval-fails-with-status-code-401

Answer 1

Every user have to click that link, or can an administrator fix it?

  • No, this is not something that must be initialized by each user.
  • If the message keeps appearing, it should be fixed once, centrally in IAS (or by SAP for a partner demo tenant).

What an IAS administrator would normally do in a customer-owned tenant:

  1. Log on to the IAS administrator console
  2. Open the application that represents CBC
  3. Check:
    • Default Identity Provider for the application
    • Any configured Login Hint parameter
  4. Make sure the origin key that is passed in login_hint (or configured as xsuaa.origin / Default IdP) matches an existing, active IdP in IAS
  5. Save / activate.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/authenticating-identity-provider-for-application

Once this is corrected:

  • All users will be routed to the right IdP automatically again.
  • The red box with origin provided in the login hint is invalid disappears for everyone no need for each user to click anything.

In a partner demo environment

For a partner demo Public Cloud system, IAS and CBC are usually managed by SAP (or by your partner admin, not by end-users). In that case:

  • You normally don’t have the IAS admin role for that tenant
  • If the error persists, the right approach is to open an SAP support incident (component BC-IAM-IDS) and attach your screenshot and CBC URL

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/getting-support?version=Cloud

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/b60dd89024994573873a231502d4ddd4.html1

Answer 2

It’s purely an authentication routing problem, not a CBC data problem.

Typical impact:

  • You may not get automatic SSO into CBC, instead you see the blue IAS page with the warning and must pick an IdP/link
  • Until you do that, you cannot access CBC in that browser session.

What is not affected:

  • CBC projects, configuration activities, transports, Cloud configuration etc. are untouched this is before you even reach CBC
  • Your Public Cloud system login itself usually uses a different IAS application and can work fine at the same time

Potentially affected in more complex landscapes:

  • Any other apps that reuse the same IAS application and the same invalid origin could show the same message or fail automated token requests with origin provided in login_hint does not match an active Identity Provider

For your scenario (partner demo CBC):

  • It is almost certainly limited to the CBC login and does not corrupt or change any CBC or Public Cloud configuration.

Answer 3

Technically, IAS is evaluating an OAuth/SAML request that contains a login_hint with an origin field (something like {"origin":"someIdPKey"}), and:

  • that origin key does not exist,
  • or exists but is disabled for that application,
  • or was changed/renamed in IAS while the application still uses the old value

Typical concrete triggers:

  1. Change in IAS configuration
    • Someone modified the IdP setup (renamed an origin key, disabled a corporate IdP, changed default IdP, adjusted login-hint rules) for the CBC application.
  2. System refresh / new tenant / partner demo housekeeping
    • SAP or the landscape owner refreshed or re-provisioned the partner demo and the IAS–CBC trust configuration changed slightly.
    • The link you use to go from Public Cloud to CBC still contains a login_hint for the previous IdP origin.

When you manually click ayge3zpo2.accounts.cloud.sap:

  • You bypass the invalid login_hint routing and directly choose a valid IdP (the local IAS user store).
  • IAS authenticates you, creates a session, and the CBC call then succeeds.

So the trigger is platform-level identity configuration, not anything you did in CBC or Public Cloud customizing.

Summary and practically recommend for you

Since this is a partner demo Public Cloud environment:

  1. If the error was only once and now you get SSO into CBC without seeing that screen again, you can treat it as a one-off IAS routing glitch.
  2. If it keeps happening
    • Collect:
      • CBC URL,
      • timestamp,
      • screenshot with the error.
    • Raise an incident for BC-IAM-IDS (SAP Cloud Identity Services Identity Authentication), mention that CBC login for your Public Cloud partner demo shows: The origin provided in the login hint is invalid
    • Ask them to check the IdP origin / login_hint configuration for the CBC application in your IAS tenant.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Conversion Path from ECC 6.0 EHP 8 on HANA to S/4HANA 2025 On-premise
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We are currently evaluating our options for migrating our existing SAP ERP system to S/4HANA and would greatly appreciate some input from those with conversion experience.

Our current system landscape details are:

* **System:** SAP ERP 6.0
* **Enhancement Package:** EHP 8
* **Database:** SAP HANA

My primary technical question is:

**Is our current system (ECC 6.0 EHP 8 on SAP HANA) technically supported and compatible for a direct System Conversion (Brownfield) to the upcoming SAP S/4HANA 2025 On-premise Edition?**

---

**Context on Conversion Strategy:**

We have been speaking with our local SAP Account Executives, and they have strongly indicated that the only viable path for us moving forward is through the **RISE with SAP** offering (Cloud/Hyperscaler model).

I am specifically looking for validation regarding the *technical feasibility* of the **On-premise** conversion path. My understanding is that ECC 6.0 EHP 8 on HANA should technically be a good starting point for a direct conversion to S/4HANA On-premise.

Has anyone in the community successfully completed, or is currently planning, a conversion from this specific source release (ECC 6.0 EHP 8 on HANA) to a recent or future On-premise S/4HANA release (like 2023 or 2025)?

Thank you in advance for sharing your expertise!

entry.title: Limitations when automating Maintenance Plan Creation in SAP Sales Cloud
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We are currently working on a development that should automatically create Maintenance Plans in SAP Sales Cloud, 

Solution Version 2511.01.0003, based on a specific trigger. However, we have identified two major issues.

1. No programmatic access to key Maintenance Plan fields (Plan Definition tab)

We have found that:

  • The Plan Definition structure (ConditionGroup) in the Maintenance Plan is read-only.
  • The fields that define the plan frequency - specifically the Condition and Value fields- cannot be written or modified via SDK, nor via publicly available APIs:

This means that even though a Maintenance Plan object can theoretically be created via development, it would be incomplete, since the essential scheduling parameters cannot be filled programmatically.

We would like to know:

  • Is there any SAP-supported way to enable write access to this structure?

  • Is there an alternative API or workaround that SAP recommends? 

  • If not currently available, can SAP consider enabling write access to this object in the Public Solution Model?

 

2. Data Workbench Template also does not allow uploading scheduling values

We tried loading Maintenance Plans using Data Workbench, but the upload template also doesn't allow filling in the required frequency values. The template only allows fields like:

  • Schedule Type
  • Schedule Condition

But there is no way to populate the “Value” and “Unit” fields of the Plan Definition, even though these are mandatory for a complete and usable Maintenance Plan.

This leads to a key question:

  • How can SAP provide mass upload functionality for Maintenance Plans in Data Workbench if the upload template does not include the fields required to define the plan frequency?

Summarizing, we are blocked because:

  • We cannot set scheduling values programmatically (SDK or APIs).

  • We cannot load them via Data Workbench either.

  • Without these values, Maintenance Plans cannot generate Tickets automatically — which is the fundamental purpose of the object.

Any guidance from SAP experts or product owners would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: SAP Build Process Automation – Configuring Microsoft 365 email provider for SMTP mail destinatio
entry.content:
Hello @vincent00 ,

Thank you for reaching out. Here are a few things to check:

1. Verify the destination name: The destination must be named exactly: sap_process_automation_mail (case-sensitive).

2. Allow time for synchronization: After creating or modifying a destination in the BTP Cockpit, there's a brief synchronization period with your SAP Build Process Automation tenant. This typically takes only a few seconds, but please allow up to a minute for the destination to appear.

3. Confirm the destination location: Ensure the destination was created in the same subaccount as your SAP Build Process Automation tenant.

If the destination still doesn't appear after verifying these points, I'll need access to tenant-specific information and logs to investigate further. Please open a support ticket so our team can access your tenant details and provide more detailed assistance.

Best regards,

Erwan

entry.title: Giving Back: Ticket Revenue from SAP Inside Track Fortaleza Donated to Associação Estação da Luz
entry.content:
I’m proud to share that we have completed the donation of 100% of the ticket revenue from SAP Inside Track Fortaleza to Associação Estação da Luz, a social organization located in Messejana, in the Greater Fortaleza area.

As has become tradition at all SAP Inside Track Fortaleza editions, all ticket income is directed to a local social project. This year, the chosen institution was Estação da Luz, whose work has a meaningful impact on the lives of children and young people in the community.

We also had the privilege of closing the event with a beautiful performance by the association’s youth choir — a moment that touched everyone and highlighted the importance of supporting initiatives that create opportunities through education, culture, and social development.

A big thank you to all participants, speakers, sponsors, and volunteers who made this edition possible. Your engagement directly contributes to strengthening the local community and extending the impact of the SAP ecosystem beyond technology.

Together, we build knowledge, connection, and social purpose.

entry.title: SAP PAPM - the role of business calculation engine in a business steering
entry.content:
Picture 1. End-to-end profitability and performance management

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organization is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organizational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognizing these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organizational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organizations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support – going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimize resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today’s business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering 
  2.  Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC  
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC 
  4. Is AI going to “retire” a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today’s volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC 
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. SAP PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering (THIS BLOG POST)
  9. Self – service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

INTRODUCTION

In today’s fast-paced business environment, enterprises must be flexible and adaptable to evolving market conditions and customer expectations. As a result, companies are developing strategies focused on innovation, digital transformation, and sustainable growth. However, when it comes to execution, the benefits of these strategic initiatives often fall short of expectations.

Why the Gap?

Several factors contribute to the disconnect between strategy and execution:

  • Insufficient analysis and adaptation to business changes, making strategies difficult to execute in real-world conditions.
  • Weak integration between financial and operational models, leading to misaligned decisions.
  • Lack of trust in the numbers due to data silos and overly complex reporting models.
  • Poor visibility into root causes of performance, whether underperformance or overachievement.

This is where the concept of Enterprise Performance Management (EPM) becomes critical. EPM serves as the bridge between strategic goals and day-to-day execution. SAP offers a comprehensive, end-to-end EPM framework that spans planning, consolidation, tax, and sustainability management.

Despite advancements, organizations still face hurdles in their EPM processes, that are highly connected to the reasons for the gap between strategy and execution:

  • New regulations and market dynamics
  • Data  silos and disconnected processes
  • Limited business context in performance reporting

To address these, companies increasingly need a business semantics calculation engine as an important part of their EPM framework —a solution that connects transactional and planning data to management reporting in real time. Such an engine should enable:

  • Business-user-driven modeling through a no-code/low-code environment
  • Integration of business semantics (e.g., cost allocations, profitability logic) into real-time calculations, powered by solutions like SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Simulation and scenario analysis without IT dependency

Let’s explore how a business semantics calculation engine can bring value across different scenarios not only for actuals, but also for planning data:

  • Regulatory reporting: Ensure compliance with traceable, rule-based calculations.
  • Profitability analysis: Evaluate performance by customer segment, region, channel, or product line.
  • Bill of Materials (BOM) simulation and explosion: Assess the impact of changing prices or quantities on semi-finished and final products.
  • Operational transfer pricing: Maintain compliance and transparency in cross-border pricing models.
  • Group cost calculations: Enable unified and transparent cost modeling across entities.

For instance, in a BOM simulation, users can assess how price or quantity changes at the component level affect the cost of the final product. This often involves recursive, high-volume calculations. By using SAP S/4HANA for transactional data, enriching it with SAP Profitability and Performance Management (SAP PaPM), and feeding the results into SAP Analytics Cloud, businesses can maintain full transparency, auditability, and planning granularity.

Another example: planned profitability calculations at the SKU level. While this level of detail may be unnecessary in the core budgeting process, it's critical for management reporting. Rather than overburdening the core planning system, businesses can offload these complex calculations to a dedicated engine and integrate the results seamlessly.

Last but not the least example to illustrate the need in business calculation engine is a group costing calculation. Let's say the company has many intercompany relationships, products and services are going through various steps between companies in this process. SAP PAPM delivers real-time insights into group margin, through segmented profit and loss reports according to key transfer pricing dimensions, providing needed data to manage and analyze tax costs and revenues, markups and markup costs, production and services costs and third-party revenues.

Benefits of Embedding a Calculation Engine into the Planning Process

  • Automate complex allocations and business logic
  • Ensure full transparency and auditability
  • Enable granular planning and analysis—by customer, product, channel, etc.
  • Increase compliance by following new regulations

From the business user’s perspective, this process should be seamless. As a planner, you simply run the calculation and see results immediately integrated into your planning reports. This is precisely the kind of user-centric experience enabled by the SAP EPM framework—combining SAP S/4HANA, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Profitability and Performance Management (SAP PaPM).

Picture 2. Detailed Profitability analysis powered by SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP PAPM

WHAT IS SAP PAPM? 

SAP PaPM Cloud is a no-code calculation engine that empowers business users to model and execute complex logic without IT intervention. It processes large data volumes at high speed and supports a wide range of EPM scenarios.

Key capabilities include:

  • Extending standardized processes in SAP S/4HANA with custom logic and allocations
  • Enabling business users to model complex rules without coding
  • Processing massive data sets in-memory via SAP HANA
  • Integrating data from SAP and non-SAP sources, hosted on SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Creating financial documents, postings to general or group ledger, and more in SAP S/4HANA enabling an end-to-end process, and not just running as a disconnected calculation engine
  • Ensuring full traceability from results to source data

Picture 3. SAP Profitability and Performance Management

SAP PAPM and SAP BUSINESS DATA CLOUD

SAP PAPM can on top of BDC, in this case data persistency and processing happens on the SAP Datasphere level in SAP BDC. With SAP BDC Data products we can ensure context-rich data from SAP and non- SAP sources being available for PAPM calculations, building a foundation for detailed transparent analysis and also providing even more data for AI-powered insights.  Another benefit of placing SAP PAPM on top of SAP BDC is that with SAC being also part of the platform, we can really ensure end-to-end EPM processes without data replication, leveraging seamless planning and when needed extending calculations with SAP PAPM engine to achieve even greater transparency and performance.  Ream more about BDC components in our previous blog "Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)"

Picture 4. SAP Business Data Cloud components

Let’s take a look at the data flow for a corporate profitability analysis within an SAP landscape.
The initial data originates in the transactional system or system of record, SAP S/4HANA. While S/4HANA already provides capabilities for cost calculation and allocation, we can further enrich this data with performance results and details—such as customer segment, region, channel, or product line—and incorporate simulations.

To achieve this, we introduce an additional BDC-based layer that leverages BDC data products and SAP Datasphere to connect to S/4HANA, as well as other potential data sources and prepare the data. SAP PaPM then performs the calculations, and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) visualizes the results and provides a planning-process framework for end users.

Picture 5. Corporate profitability analysis with SAP solutions

Conclusion

A business semantics calculation engine is a powerful tool in enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of EPM processes. Whether it’s for tax, transfer pricing, profitability modelling, or planning enhancements, SAP Profitability and Performance Management plays an important role in bridging the gap between transactional data and reporting requirements.

By embedding SAP PaPM within your EPM architecture, you can equip business users to act even faster, have greater insights, and align execution more closely with strategic intent. SAP Business Data cloud will provide a proven semantically reach data foundation and AI tools to simplify analysis, we will be giving more detailed examples in our next articles. 

Looking to take the next step? Connect with your SAP representative to register for an SAP BDC Discovery Workshop.
To expand your expertise in SAP PaPM, consider exploring the related blog series published within the SAP Community  and stay tuned for more.

entry.title: Re: ABAP Proxy generation support with SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Hi @radhika_javvaji , @KevinSong 

My issue is now resolved. The proxy objects were there but under a different bucket. I followed steps below:

1- Run t-code SPROXY.

2- Goto menu Utilities --> Settings

3- Scroll to the tab Proxy Generation and change the Enterprise Service Browser setting to "D Enterprise Service Browser"

4- Back out and re-run SPROXY. 

5- Follow node Source --> ESR --> SWCs and you will see your custom integration packages there.

Note:- Choose Re-usable option while migrating your SAP PO interfaces to integration suite. Otherwise, no objects will be created in the backend.

Hope it helps.

Regards,

Kamran

entry.title: Vendor Automatically Changes to Head Office Vendor During Supplier Invoice Posting in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are working on SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud 3SL in India localization.

Our supplier has multiple GST registrations across different states, so we created one vendor BP for each GSTIN (branch vendors). We also have one Head Office (HO) Vendor with bank details, which is maintained as the Alternative Payee for payment run purposes. This is aligned with GST design.

Expected SAP Standard Behaviour

Invoices (PO-based & non-PO) must always post to the branch vendor, because GST reporting is state-specific.

Only the APP payment run should redirect payment to the HO Vendor via Alternative Payee.

Issue We Are Facing

During supplier invoice posting (Create Supplier Invoice / MIRO equivalent), even after selecting the branch vendor, SAP automatically replaces the vendor with the HO vendor.

The system shows:

“Account has been changed: dependent data will be initialised.”

The invoice is finally posted to the HO vendor, which is incorrect for GST and vendor reconciliation.

What We Have Already Validated

No custom logic exists in Custom Logic (BAdI) app

PO is created with the correct branch vendor

Branch vendor has no bank details

HO Vendor is maintained only as Alternative Payee

No extensions are influencing vendor fields

Questions to the Community

Is this automatic replacement of vendor during invoice posting standard behaviour in S/4HANA Public Cloud 3SL?

Does Alternative Payee affect invoice posting, or only the payment run?

Could this be caused by BP Partner Functions (FLVN01 → Purchasing → Partner Functions)?

Should SSCUI 102561 (Partner Determination for Supplier) or 102617 (Supplier Account Groups) be checked for default partner assignments?

What is the correct SAP recommended configuration for multi-GST vendor scenarios where invoice must post to branch vendor and payment must go to HO vendor?

We need a confirmation from SAP experts because invoice posting to HO vendor breaks GST compliance and vendor-level ageing.

 

Thanks in advance for your guidance.

entry.title: Re: Implementing BAPI_CONTRACT_CHANGE
entry.content:
@FabioMendona

Fabio,

We did this change for BAPI_PO_CHANGE

We did not implement any other BADIs or Exits, but, an existing user exit was posing a problem. EXIT_SAPMM06E_016

It was not a problem in ECC but in S4 it was. Had to add this as first block in user exit.

IF i_no_screen EQ abap_true "Called by Function ( BAPI )
   OR i_aktyp EQ 'A'.

  " This is being called by a Function module ( BAPI ) or Called in Dialog in Display mode
  " During display, data derivation should not happen

  ekpo_ci = CORRESPONDING ekpo_ci( i_ekpo ).

  RETURN.

ENDIF.

entry.title: Re: Review Customer Projects - Business Requirement: Peri...
entry.content:
Dear @bangaru198251,

below is a proposal of your requirements and available functionalities in the Public Cloud system, while maintaining the clean-core and Cloud-friendly.

Story 1

Plan monthly effort in hours, use Plan Customer Projects

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F0719')/S35

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/29cf986299714386847f4d4c9bb86994/21218854c46ee75ee10000000a44176d.html

  • For each work package /role you can see availability per month and manually redistribute effort across periods of the work package (months in your case)
  • That gives you a true time-phased baseline for effort and thus planned costs (since planned cost = hours × cost rate)

Run the monthly forecast review, use Review Customer Projects + Set Forecast Month:

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/29cf986299714386847f4d4c9bb86994/1a8fa3529556495592a29cdda3f70824.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/29cf986299714386847f4d4c9bb86994/2c41db55e8187816e10000000a44538d.html

How variance is handled

SAP standard logic when you set / change the forecast month is:

  • Variances between planned and actual efforts and expenses before the new forecast month are plugged into the forecast month rather than being spread automatically across future months

So the system does calculate variance, but it concentrates it in the forecast month, not distributed into all remaining months

Get the forecast into Finance by period

Use Transfer Project Forecast to Finance:

  • This job takes the confirmed forecast from Review Customer Projects and creates / updates CO plan data in Finance, time-phased by period
  • Unlike Review Customer Projects, it looks at all actuals, not only up to the forecast month

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/29cf986299714386847f4d4c9bb86994/5d577318fb924200877a167566837e81.html

Story 2

How cost rates work in Public Cloud

  • Manage Cost Rates Services
    Define cost rates for professional services for combinations like: company code, receiving cost center, activity type, service cost level, employee (personnel number), work item and even WBS element

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c56f622a2edf491b9f1b596b55587009/9fca5b12d8df4591a240100305da6357.html

  • Manage Cost Rates Plan
    Maintain planned activity prices by period (fiscal year/month) and ledger; these feed planning and (depending on set-up) can be used as the standard rate during the period

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c56f622a2edf491b9f1b596b55587009/bd39911453324bf7900cccb4531e206e.html

  • Manage Cost Rates Actual
    Store actual cost rates, manually or via Actual Cost Rate Calculation at period end. These override the other rates if maintained

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c56f622a2edf491b9f1b596b55587009/10c16133145f4f0ca9be1e9e3e4a6cdd.html

All these apps support time-dependency

Story 3

This is where standard functionality diverges from your requirement.

  • Employees record time using Manage My Timesheet
  • In the Professional Services scenario, process steps include:
    • Record time
    • Approve timesheet entries
    • Transfer time recordings to target components

Key points:

  • Once a time entry is transferred to CO/Project, cost is posted immediately based on the cost rate determination

SAP Note with details:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002951857

  • You can back post time into past periods as long as FI/CO periods are open so Timesheet entries can be posted for past periods when rates become available is standard

This means:

    • You do see provisional cost during the month.
    • But the final period cost equals hours × final rate, without needing to buffer hours.
    • Revenue recognition in customer projects already works with dynamic/confirmed EAC logic and will adjust PoC based on updated costs

Side-by-side BTP extension

If your business requirement is truly absolutely no cost postings before rate approval, you’d need a side-by-side design

Story 4

Standard month-end sequence

  1. Close time and billing for the month
    • Ensure timesheets are complete and transferred
    • Run project billing as needed
  2. Set Forecast Month
    • Use Set Forecast Month to set the current closed month as the forecast reference.
    • This controls which actuals are shown in Review Customer Projects and how previous variances are rolled into the forecast month

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/29cf986299714386847f4d4c9bb86994/1a8fa3529556495592a29cdda3f70824.html

  1. Review Customer Projects
  2. Transfer Project Forecast to Finance
    • Run the job so that your updated forecast is written into time-phased financial plan data

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/29cf986299714386847f4d4c9bb86994/5d577318fb924200877a167566837e81.html

https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-blog-posts-by-sap/financial-planned-data-in-professional-services-by-project-financial/ba-p/14241364

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/89d896ca9cd64318b1667df5ec00e4b2/5e6d33c7a74d4c528d496dde89c8957c.html

  1. Repeat next month
    • Next month, set the forecast month forward and repeat the cycle so you’re literally working sequentially month by month.

Summary:

  • Story 1 and 4 can be covered with standard Public Cloud (Professional Services) using: Plan Customer Projects, Review Customer Projects, Set Forecast Month and Transfer Project Forecast to Finance
  • Story 2 time-dependent rates are fully standard via Manage Cost Rates Services / Plan / Actual. The system works with validity periods and rate overrides (even down to WBS)
  • Story 3 the hold hours until rates exist, then post once is not how Public Cloud works in standard

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: 🇰🇼 Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core (Doha, QA)
entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam event is on the topic of Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core with Python. You don't need any prior background in the topic, but you should have a strong curiosity and basic coding skills.

In this SAP CodeJam, you will learn how to use Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core to implement a retrieval augmented generation (RAG) use case to improve the responses of large language models (LLMs) and reduce hallucinations. You will learn how to work with LLMs and the orchestration service on SAP AI Core and query it via SAP AI Launchpad and the Python SDK. Furthermore, you will learn about the most important genAI concepts and create and use embeddings to improve your RAG response and build your own chatbot with memory. 

This is an in-person event only (not virtual, no streaming) and is planned for Wednesday, December 10, 2025, from 10:00 to 16:00 local time. The event's language and content will be in English. 

The event is being hosted by Mark9 at
Regus, D-Ring Road,
Al Mataar / Al Qadeem District, Doha

Prerequisites: Bring your own laptop with a Chromium-based web browser, such as Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, etc.

Please note that seating is limited to 20 seats and is available on a first-come, first-served basis.

entry.title: Re: splitting 100000 records to two internal tables and post in al11
entry.content:
If I understand you correctly you have one internal table with 100k entries and you want to split them into 2 internal tables with 50k entries each?

If my assumption is correct you can do a very basic approach of looping at the main table and utilizing SY-INDEX variable as a index(er) (or create a index variable yourself - which you have to increase inside the loop. Add a IF statement that checks wether or not the current index is below 50k or above and distribute the data accordingly. Either you just move data from the original iTab to a second iTab or move data from the original one to iTab1 at counter < 50k and into iTab2 when counter > 50k. The LOOP AT structure allows you to either use a field symbol (for performance optimization) or work area. I would suggest you use the field-symbol approach since it is generally faster (due to the lack of the need for memory allocation) since you are working with a field symbol instead of moving data from the tab to a work area.

There are also other methods that involve more advanced language features like the VALUE keyword but depending on your needs sometimes the easiest option is jus the best. If you want "the best" option you'd need to supply a bit more information.

Hope it helps and: happy coding!

Edit: I overlooked the mentioning of AL11 in the title, do you wish to split the original table into 2 and export this into a file (with a certain format)? If so it would help tremendously if you could specify a bit more what the output format should be. I imagine you need some sort of CSV format? For that the easiest way would be to use OPEN DATASET, but again: more details needed 😅

My formula looks as follows:

//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
//The data region against which the formulas will be executed.
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
MEMBERSET [d/PSPELEMENT] = BASEMEMBER([d/PSPELEMENT].[h/PSPHIER], %PSPElemBaseMember%)
MEMBERSET [d/Date] = %STARTDATUM% TO %ENDDATUM%
MEMBERSET [d/Parametertyp] = "100"
MEMBERSET [d/VTYPE] = %VTYPE%
MEMBERSET [d/PERSONAL] = %Mitarbeiter%

//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
//Calculation and Data Writing
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
MODEL [APC_BASIC_DATA]
ENDMODEL

FOREACH [d/PERSONAL], [APC_BASIC_DATA].[d/VALIDFROM] ASC
	IF DATEDIFF([d/Date], [APC_BASIC_DATA].[d/VALIDFROM], "MONTH") >= 0 THEN
		IF LINK([APC_BASIC_DATA], [d/Measures] = "Betrag", [d/PSPELEMENT] = %PSPElemQuelle%, [d/Parametertyp] = "1", [d/Version] = "public.Actual", [d/Date] = "000000") > 0 THEN

			DATA([d/Measures] = "Umsatz") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "STUNDEN") * LINK([APC_BASIC_DATA], [d/Measures] = "Betrag", [d/PSPELEMENT] = %PSPElemQuelle%, [d/Parametertyp] = "1", [d/Version] = "public.Actual", [d/Date] = "000000")

		ENDIF
	ENDIF
ENDFOR

The purpose of this function is to find the correct hourly rate for each data record in the main model and then to calculate the revenue.

The FOREACH should check for each employee and validfrom whether the month of the current record in the main model is greater than or equal to the validfrom month of the linked model. By sorting in ascending order, I ensure that the hourly rate with the largest validfrom month is calculated last and that each hour is calculated with the correct hourly rate.

The problem is that the LINK command within the FOREACH does not take the validfrom value of the current iteration. It seems as if it takes the aggregation of all hourly rates for an employee.

How can I specify the filter for the validfrom dimension of the current iteration in the LINK command?

Thanks in advance.

Kind regards,
Max

entry.title: Re: How to reference child object in another custom MDF o...
entry.content:
Hi syeapAB,

 

According to KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/0003383815 it is not recommended to configure a child object in another MDF Object as a Generic Object reference field and the system will throw the error message you received.

But the data updating from UI (manage data, people profile.etc) may work, however, it may not work for MDF import / Odata API scenarios to update MDF data, the Odata API updating or the MDF import will fail.

 

Regards,

Cristian

entry.title: TechEd Recap: Creating AI-Enhanced UX for Your Own Applications with SAP Design System
entry.content:
By Sophia Levens and Thomas Reiss

We were thrilled to speak at this year’s TechEd conference in Berlin on how the SAP Design System is powering the next generation of AI-led product design. Our Deep Dive talk entitled “Creating AI-enhanced UX for your own applications with SAP Design System” focused on three key areas: an introduction into the SAP Design System, new AI patterns for the design system and SAPUI5, and our AI-powered tools for our UI technologies. We then closed the session with an overview of the resources available to designers and developers today.

Below we’ll share a recap of the major points and announcements from the session. You can also watch the recorded session here.

 

Introduction to the SAP Design System

The overall mission of the SAP Design System is to unify and advance the SAP user experience. We achieve this in two ways:

  • Unify: The SAP Design System serves as the central hub of ready-to-use assets, guidance and standards for building delightful experiences that are consistent across the SAP portfolio. This is how we directly contribute to SAP’s Suite-First strategy.
  • Advance: The SAP Design System provides the essential patterns and tools to embed transformative AI experiences across all products and touchpoints. This is how we directly contribute to the AI-First goal.

What exactly is a design system?

In order to deliver consistent and inclusive UX, the SAP Design System is made up of the following elements:

  1. Design Language: The most foundational elements that go into any brand. For example, color, type, iconography, illustrations, etc.
  2. Components: The building blocks for creating user interfaces, like buttons, drop down menus, or input fields.
  3. Patterns: Covers a use case or user flow, things like exporting data to PDF or a search workflow.
  4. Floorplans: A full UI layout. Typically, floorplans are a complete page or even span several pages.

The SAP Design System extends across SAP. It helps to unify all touchpoints across the SAP brand including our products, our digital experiences like sap.com, and other marketing and communications including interactive events like TechEd. And because the system is open source, our customers can also use the design system to build upon and customize our products and platforms.

What UI technologies are supported with the SAP Design System?

For each element in the SAP Design System, we build reusable components in code that developers can leverage to accelerate their workflow. There are two ways to leverage SAP technologies—via “floorplans and building blocks” or “freestyle”.

  • Build “freestyle” with SAPUI5 and SAP Web Components: Freestyle allows you full control of every element on the screen.
  • Use “floorplans and building blocks” with SAP Fiori Elements: This lets you accelerate development when the desired app or workflow is close to one of the out-of-the box floorplans or building blocks.

Because both of these choices are based on SAPUI5, you don’t have to choose one or the other, you can mix both ways of developing leveraging each when needed.

 

New AI Patterns for the SAP Design System and SAPUI5

SAP is proud to offer AI components and patterns for web and mobile. We’re investing in making it easy to design and build great AI experiences that are responsible, flexible, and work across ecosystems. Our AI experience principles are built on the following six pillars: design for clarity, earn trust, give control, design fairly, boost flow, fail-safe.

Find the latest AI patterns and components:

  • SAP Design System portal
  • SAP Web UI Kit
  • SAP Fiori for iOS UI Kit
  • SAP Fiori for Android UI Kit
  • UI5 Web Components

Our AI components and patterns have gone through the process of reviews and testing by our experts in user assistance, accessibility, user research, and are compliant with SAP’s legal and ethical AI standards. These are patterns you and your users can trust.

 

Using our AI-powered UI Technologies to Help You Build Faster

We have introduced powerful AI tools to help you build UIs and applications faster.

SAP Joule for Developers is a collection of embedded AI capabilities for SAP Build as well as for ABAP, delivered through Joule, that accelerates development of apps and extensions, reduces costs, and improves developer proficiency.

The SAP Fiori tools project accelerator, which can be started from Joule in SAP Build Code, enables developers to create CAP-based (Cloud Application Programming model based) SAP Fiori elements applications directly from an image of the intended outcome. These images can be high fidelity Figma models, lower fidelity screenshots or a sketch on paper. Simply upload the image and use AI to generate the data models, services and the UI. Find out more in this blog post: From idea to app: using AI-powered Project Accelerator to develop SAP Fiori apps.

 Generate a complete CAP-based application from a sketch with SAP Fiori tools project accelerator: data models, services and UI.

Recently, we have gone even further and introduced MCP servers for freestyle SAPUI5 development as well as for developing with SAP Fiori elements and the associated building blocks. These open-source Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers equip developers with valuable support by providing AI agents with comprehensive UI5 and SAP Fiori elements knowledge, including best practices and project-aware context information.

Read about the new MCP servers in these blog posts:

  • UI5 MCP Server.
  • MCP Server for SAP Fiori.

Key Takeaways

This deep dive session gave an overview of how customers and partners can create AI-enhanced UX for their own applications with the SAP Design System and SAP’s UI technologies. Find everything you need to get started designing and developing:

  • Get started with the SAP Design System portal.
  • Use SAP's UI kits with the new AI patterns.
  • Use SAPUI5.

entry.title: Re: SolMan 7.2 RFC unable to set to confirmed in producti...
entry.content:
To limit this situation from happening again, I suggest configuring the predecessor-successor status attributes (Specify Status Attributes) so the incident status cannot be confirmed until the successor RFC is confirmed, or whatever status values your business case requires. For example, we've configured the incident transaction so that before it can be set to Proposed Solution, the successor RFC must have one of the statuses, Implemented, Confirmed, or Withdrawn.

Proceed with caution: But, to update an RFC where the predecessor incident is already closed, you might consider using the report, CRM_SOCM_SERVICE_REPORT. Please read the fine documentation for the report. This report can update the status of a transaction (or set of transactions), but will not make the consistency checks built into the application. Be sure of what you're about to do, and use the "List Output Only (No Update)" option to check the selected transaction(s), etc., before committing updates.

entry.title: What’s New for Joule in SAP Fieldglass – November 2025
entry.content:
Joule in SAP Fieldglass was first introduced in July, and since then its capabilities have continued to expand. Our latest November 2025 release brings several key enhancements designed to streamline processes, boost efficiency, and improve accessibility and inclusivity for users globally.

What’s New for Joule in the SAP Fieldglass November 2025 Release:

  • Multi-Language Support
    Joule can now automatically detect the user’s input language, interacting and responding in the user’s preferred language

 

  • Translated Templates and Report Retrieval
    For organizations that translate Job Posting Templates, SOW Templates, and Reports, Joule will identify the user’s preferred language and retrieve the corresponding localized version when available.

 

  •  Simplified Job Posting Template Recommendations
    Users can now describe their needs in natural language. Joule will interpret the requirement and retrieve relevant templates—removing the previous dependency on specific job titles.

 

  • Decision Form Approvals
    Users can now approve or reject Decision Forms directly within Joule when reviewing their pending Work Items, making the approval process faster and more intuitive.

 

  • Legal Entity Recognition
    When Legal Entity functionality is enabled, users can include the Legal Entity as part of their requirements when creating Job Postings or Statements of Work. Joule will recognize and automatically populate the correct value in the appropriate documents.

Want to Learn More?

Watch our short Joule Release Highlights video demonstrating these items.

Explore our Joule in SAP Fieldglass Help Portal page for a comprehensive overview of the tool and its current capabilities.

Visit the SAP Community for additional release resources and the latest AI insights.

entry.title: Adoption Isn’t a Phase, It’s a Relationship
entry.content:
If you know me, you know I love an analogy. It’s always helpful to make new information make sense by likening it to something we already understand.

In my role here at SAP, I talk about adoption a lot. It’s a point that I (and my wonderful team, Solution Value Advisory) really push with our customers, who sometimes think of adoption as a step in the overall process, something you do after go-live.  So, my analogy for today is to look at adoption like a relationship, because it’s never just about the software, but about the people and how they interact with the system and each other.

It’s not much of a stretch, really. At the start, it’s a mix of excitement, a little confusion, and commitment that comes with bringing something new into your life, and hoping it thrives, grows, and has the support of people around you.


The honeymoon stage
 In my last role several years back, I worked on Ariba solution implementations. Being on a shared services team, I got to stick my hands into a lot of different customers’ Ariba deployments. It felt great, for the customer and for me, to reach what felt like a finish line: go-live. That point of the new solution(s) going live after months of setup and testing. The vibes were always good - everyone was hopeful, users explored the system, performed tests. Teams got trained. There was that spark of possibility, that sense of this time, things will be different.

But just like any new relationship, the shine fades if the day-to-day connection isn’t nurtured. Old habits creep back in, shortcuts resurface. And, before long, that beautiful new tool starts gathering dust.  Remember, adoption doesn’t end at go-live, that’s when it begins.


Relationships thrive on consistency, and so do systems
Healthy adoption looks a lot like a healthy partnership: steady, intentional, and full of small moments that build trust.

It’s when someone logs in and sees that their preferences were remembered. It’s when data syncs across systems, so people stop fighting with spreadsheets and endless back-and-forth email. It’s when users realize the tool makes their jobs easier, not harder. It keeps the relationship alive.

But breakdowns don’t usually happen with a bang, but a fizzle. Users don’t revolt, they quietly disengage. They skip the process “just this once.” Then they stop trusting the data, because the process is getting skipped and they can’t find what they were looking for. And now something that was originally set up to create efficiency is now only causing frustration, and becomes a pain in the…well, you know. 😊

In my work with customers, I see this all the time.  I work a lot with customers on their supplier management processes especially, and I see a lot of this disengagement when it comes to onboarding. Tools like SAP Cloud Identity Services and SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle & Performance (SLP) can be super powerful, but they depend on trusted data and consistency. If people don’t understand why something matters, they won’t invest in making it work.

The love language of AI is good data
Now we’re entering a new chapter, one where AI tools like SAP Joule are ready to help make our jobs easier. But even Joule, which might seem like magic when you see it presented, needs a foundation of trust. This has been my main message of the year - reminding people that AI doesn’t make magic out of thin air, rather it builds on what we give it. If data is messy, disconnected, or if established processes are underused, Joule’s insights will be, too.

(Pausing here for a shoutout to anyone who was at the Customer Success Day in NYC earlier this year where I did a whole session to essentially say, “Garbage in, garbage out”. The highlight, at least to me, was my AI-generated Ariba song parody of Naughty by Nature’s O.P.P.  Who’s down with SLP? Yeah you know me!)

But back to my relationship analogy, think of it this way: if you never talk to your partner, you can’t expect them to finish your sentences. Joule works the same way. The relationship only deepens when we communicate through connected, clean, and well-adopted systems. 


Adoption is ongoing care.
As I said before, adoption isn’t a task. We don’t “complete” adoption. We maintain it. We check in with our users, we update them on changes, and we listen when something isn’t working and adjust before resentment sets in.  The most successful customers I see are those who treat adoption as a living process. Not just implementing technology, but inviting it into their company culture. When adoption is healthy, everything else (innovation, automation, AI, etc.) starts to flow naturally.  But just like any great relationship, it takes attention, empathy, and patience.


I encourage you all to stay in tune with our roadmap, as there’s a lot of exciting stuff to come in 2026 when it comes to AI in SAP. But as you read up on that and start to think how cool it will be and how much time it will save to have all of those new capabilities, remember that now is the time to build the foundation for that new relationship. 

If you have any doubts about how well your company is adopting your solutions and how you’re doing on usage in comparison to other customers, do reach out to your CSM who can either help, or can pull in the right people to have that conversation. Sometimes that person is me, so say hi and maybe I'll share my library of Ariba song parodies.

entry.title: Re: sac advanced formula - searching for the right record...
entry.content:
Shortly after writing the post, I found the solution. 

1. My DATEDIFF function was defined incorrectly.

2. The aggregation did not come via the LINK command but is contained in the DATA statement.

Here is the corrected code:

MODEL [APC_BASIC_DATA]
ENDMODEL

FOREACH [d/PERSONAL], [APC_BASIC_DATA].[d/VALIDFROM] ASC
	IF DATEDIFF([APC_BASIC_DATA].[d/VALIDFROM], [d/Date], "MONTH") >= 0 THEN
		IF LINK([APC_BASIC_DATA], [d/Measures] = "Betrag", [d/PSPELEMENT] = %PSPElemQuelle%, [d/Parametertyp] = "1", [d/Version] = "public.Actual", [d/Date] = "000000") > 0 THEN

			DATA([d/Measures] = "Umsatz") = 0
			DATA([d/Measures] = "Umsatz") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "STUNDEN") * LINK([APC_BASIC_DATA], [d/Measures] = "Betrag", [d/PSPELEMENT] = %PSPElemQuelle%, [d/Parametertyp] = "1", [d/Version] = "public.Actual", [d/Date] = "000000")

		ENDIF
	ENDIF
ENDFOR

kind regards,
Max

entry.title: Re: PIR Update Based on RFQ
entry.content:
For Info Record updates from the supplier quotation process using Manage RFQ and Manage Supplier Quotation apps, the scheduled reports FOLLOW_ON_FROM_QUOTATION, which are essential for  updating the Info Records,  runs in the background for info record update
